nodes.text: An IoT based system using Node MCU and Arduino can provide integrated smart security and smart home automation with remote control over Wi-Fi or cellular networks, overcoming short-range limitations of existing wireless methods
Design claim: The proposed system integrates sensors (IR, MQ135, DHT11), relays, OV7670 camera, Node MCU and Arduino UNO to provide security alerts, appliance control and environment monitoring
Method: Node MCU is used as the central IoT controller for sensors and appliance control; the OV7670 camera is connected to Arduino UNO because Node MCU has only one analog pin

Context and motivation: Existing wireless home automation methods (Bluetooth, voice recognition over Bluetooth, ZigBee, GSM) suffer from limited range, sensitivity to noise, and message delivery unreliability

Result claim: The prototype sends captured images to the owner via email when IR detects motion, displays sensor values on a smartphone app every second, and allows remote switching of lights and fans
Conclusion: The implemented IoT system provides low cost, remote controllability, and dual-functionality for home security and automation and is helpful for handicapped and elderly users
Component specification: Sensors include IR for motion detection, MQ135 for air purity, DHT11 for temperature and humidity; actuators include 5V 4-channel relay board to switch appliances
Operational claim: When IR sensor detects motion the microcontroller triggers the camera, stores captured images on a PC folder, and emails the images to a predefined owner address
Implementation detail: Node MCU handles Wi-Fi communication and sensor reading; Arduino UNO handles camera interfacing and image capture due to analog pin requirements

Evidence about existing methods: Bluetooth range is limited to about 10 meters; ZigBee typical range 10-20 meters or up to 150 meters with DSSS; GSM text delivery is not always reliable; voice systems fail with low SNR
Result evidence: Prototype sensor values and alerts are viewable in the Blink smartphone app and captured OV7670 images are stored and emailed to the user
User action claim: The remote user can turn on lights and fans from their mobile device (pressing a key) after receiving an image to warn an intruder or welcome a guest
Advantages claim: The system is low cost, time saving, provides long distance control, and enhances accessibility for handicapped and aged people
Limitation: The IoT home automation system requires internet connectivity to operate remotely, though 3G or 4G can substitute for Wi-Fi
Future scope claim: The project can be reimplemented using alternative hardware such as Raspberry Pi to extend capabilities
